SENT.plain: Wilson disease is rare but proteiform, and should be suspected in any child with liver disease and older than 3 years of age
The treatment is very efficient, and must be taken life-long
Fifteen percent of patients with alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency develop a neonatal jaundice, and 3% a cirrhosis in childhood
There is no specific treatment except liver transplantation
Five percent of cystic fibrosis patients develop a cirrhosis, with a very slow progression
Milder abnormalities are frequent, as well as biliary stones
Liver disease in ciliopathies may be a congenital hepatic fibrosis, with risks of portal hypertension and cholangitis, or a more variable biliary disease
Gilbert disease is frequent and benign
Crigler-Najjar syndrome is rare, severe, and may be an indication for liver or liver-cell transplantation
